title: Are You A Classical Or Romantic Voter?

multiple-choice.question: What is an alternative way of labeling an electorate, apart from right wing and left wing?
What is a key characteristic of the romantic voter?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that a far better world could be just around the corner if only bold and swift action could be taken

options.label: B
options.text: They are highly distrustful of sudden gestures and actions

options.label: C
options.text: They consider the standard of policy across history

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that humans have deeply dangerous impulses, lusts, and drives

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern of the classical voter when it comes to policy?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the wrongdoers and respond accordingly

options.label: B
options.text: To mitigate the downside and avoid potential disasters

options.label: C
options.text: To liberate genius, strength, or benevolence

options.label: D
options.text: To contain the capacity of any one person to shift the direction of the group

multiple-choice.question: What is the romantic voter's view of people?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that humans are fundamentally rather dark

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that everyone is probably slightly worse than they seem

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that humans have deeply dangerous impulses, lusts, and drives

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that humans are inherently good

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary task of politics, according to the classical voter?

options.label: A
options.text: To try and contain humans' deeply dangerous impulses, lusts, and drives

options.label: B
options.text: To try and liberate genius, strength, beauty, or benevolence

options.label: C
options.text: To try and contain the capacity of any one person to shift the direction of the group

options.label: D
options.text: To try and make the world a better place

multiple-choice.question: What is the romantic voter's view of history?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that everything great in history is the result of institutions and circumstances

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that everything great in history is a series of random events

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that everything great in history is the result of talented individuals taking destiny into their hands

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that history is a gradual and inevitable process

multiple-choice.question: What is the classical voter's view of institutions?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that institutions are inherently corrupt and should be abolished

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that institutions are necessary to contain the capacity of any one person to shift the direction of the group

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that institutions are inefficient and should be streamlined

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that institutions are irrelevant in modern society

multiple-choice.question: What is the romantic voter's attitude towards dissenting views?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that dissenting views should be tolerated and considered

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that dissenting views should be silenced or sidelined

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that dissenting views are irrelevant and should be ignored

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that dissenting views are necessary for progress

multiple-choice.question: What is the classical voter's view of the importance of being safe in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that being safe in the world is primarily a matter of military strength

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that being safe in the world is primarily a matter of being thought well of by others

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that being safe in the world is primarily a matter of being well-prepared for potential threats

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that being safe in the world is primarily a matter of luck

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that the classical electoral attitude is outdated and irrelevant

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that the classical electoral attitude is necessary for progress and improvement

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that the classical electoral attitude is ripe for rediscovery and should be listened to more intently

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: By being well-prepared for potential threats

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question

options.label: A
options.text: Gene therapy is a method used to correct genetic diseases.

options.label: B
options.text: Gene editing technology is a method used to directly change the human genome to stop undesirable processes or make helpful substances.

options.label: C
options.text: Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation that is safe for human exposure.

options.label: D
options.text: Microgravity impairs muscle and bone growth in humans.

options.label: A
options.text: Humans can develop permanent lifesaving traits through natural adaptation.

options.label: B
options.text: Gene editing technology is a method used to accelerate human adaptation to single generations.

options.label: D
options.text: Gene editing technology is not a method used to accelerate human adaptation to single generations.

title: Can you solve the prisoner boxes riddle? - Yossi Elran

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem that the band's manager presented to them?

options.label: A
options.text: They had to write a new song for the concert.

options.label: B
options.text: They had to find their instruments, which were randomly placed in ten large boxes.

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial chance of a musician finding their instrument by picking five random boxes?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Each musician opens the box with the picture of their instrument, then the box with the picture of what they found, and so on.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Each musician opens all the boxes at the same time.

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the number of boxes opened by each musician.

options.label: B
options.text: To restrict the search to the loop that contains the instrument.

options.text: To make the search process more random.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the search process more efficient.

title: A simple way to break a bad habit

options.label: A
options.text: Their minds wander due to a lack of focus.

options.label: B
options.text: They get distracted by external stimuli.

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to quiet their minds.

According to the speaker, what is the key to breaking the spell of smoking?
What is the role of the prefrontal cortex in controlling behavior?

options.label: B
options.text: It tries to help us change our behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: It is responsible for emotional regulation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is involved in memory formation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of mindfulness?

options.label: A
options.text: It is about forcing oneself to pay attention.

options.label: B
options.text: It is about being really interested in getting close and personal with what's actually happening in our bodies and minds.

options.label: C
options.text: It is about ignoring our cravings.

options.label: D
options.text: It is about making unpleasant cravings go away as quickly as possible.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we get curious about our cravings?

options.label: B
options.text: We become more focused on the craving.

options.label: C
options.text: We start to notice that cravings are simply made up of body sensations.

options.label: D
options.text: We become less interested in our behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the default mode network, and what is its role in self-referential processing?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a network of brain regions involved in attention and executive function, and it is responsible for processing external stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a network of brain regions involved in self-referential processing, and it is activated when we get caught up in our thoughts and emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a network of brain regions involved in memory formation, and it is responsible for storing and retrieving memories.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a network of brain regions involved in motor control, and it is responsible for coordinating movement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the posterior cingulate cortex in the default mode network?

options.label: A
options.text: It is involved in attention and executive function.

options.label: B
options.text: It is activated by craving itself.

options.label: C
options.text: It is activated when we get caught up in our thoughts and emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: It is responsible for emotional regulation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of using mindfulness training to help people quit smoking?

options.label: A
options.text: To force people to quit smoking.

options.label: B
options.text: To help people become disenchanted with the behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: To use willpower to quit smoking.

options.label: D
options.text: To help people tap into their inherent capacity to be curiously aware of their thoughts and emotions.

title: The history of African-American social dance - Camille A. Brown

multiple-choice.question: What is a defining characteristic of a social dance?

options.text: It is choreographed by a single person.

options.label: C

options.text: To mock the enslaved Africans' ancestors.

options.text: To celebrate the arrival of the slave owners.

options.text: To protest against the slave trade.

options.label: D
options.text: To keep cultural traditions alive and retain a sense of inner freedom under captivity.

options.text: The mannerisms of Northern high society.

options.text: The mannerisms of Southern high society.

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of rebellion against the slave owners.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a way for young women suddenly had the freedom to kick their heels and move their legs.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a dance performed only by the enslaved Africans.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a dance that was popularized by the slave owners.

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of rebellion against the Civil Rights Movement.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It was a dance performed only by white teenagers.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a dance that was popularized by the slave owners.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between social dance and community?

options.text: Social dance is a solo performance that has no connection to community.

options.label: B
options.text: Social dance is a way for individuals to express themselves without any connection to community.

options.label: C
options.text: Social dance is a way for people to connect and belong to a group.

options.label: D
options.text: Social dance is a way for people to compete against each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the present moment in relation to social dance?

options.text: The present moment is the only time that matters in social dance.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The present moment is a time for rebellion against the past.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people dance together, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: To heal, to remember, and to say: "We speak a common language. We exist and we are free."

title: How hormones work

Conceptual Question:

options.label: C
options.text: The wood burns slowly and efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: The wood does not burn at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the remaining material after wood has been burned?
What is the primary component of charcoal?
What is the result of burning charcoal compared to burning wood?

options.label: D
options.text: Charcoal releases more heat energy with fewer smoky byproducts

multiple-choice.question: What is the main economic issue associated with the use of charcoal as a fuel source?
Why is the conservation of charcoal resources important?
What is the best course of action for individuals who want to use charcoal as a fuel source while minimizing its negative impacts?

options.label: B
options.text: To use wood as an alternative

options.label: C
options.text: To use charcoal in moderation and support sustainable forestry practices

title: What is a vector? - David Huynh

multiple-choice.question: What is a scalar quantity?

options.label: A
options.text: A quantity with magnitude, but not direction.

options.label: B
options.text: A quantity with magnitude and direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a scalar and a vector quantity?

options.label: A
options.text: A scalar has magnitude and direction, while a vector has magnitude and direction.

options.label: B
options.text: A scalar has magnitude, while a vector has magnitude and direction.

options.label: C
options.text: A scalar has direction, while a vector has magnitude only.

options.label: D
options.text: A scalar has neither magnitude nor direction, while a vector has both.

multiple-choice.question: Why are vectors useful in various fields?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they change based on perspective.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they remain invariant to the coordinate system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the essence of a vector?
What is the purpose of a coordinate basis in describing a vector?

options.label: A
options.text: To change the magnitude of the vector.

options.label: B
options.text: To change the direction of the vector.

options.label: C
options.text: To give context to the array representation and make it a vector.

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate the magnitude of the vector.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a vector and its representation in a coordinate basis?

options.label: A
options.text: The representation is the vector itself.

options.label: B
options.text: The representation is a part of the vector.

options.label: C
options.text: The representation acquires meaning as a vector when assigned a coordinate basis.

options.label: D
options.text: The representation is independent of the coordinate basis.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a second-order tensor?
What is the main property of tensors?

options.label: B
options.text: They remain invariant to the coordinate system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between scalars and tensors?

options.label: A
options.text: Scalars are a type of tensor.

options.label: B
options.text: Tensors are a type of scalar.

options.label: C
options.text: Scalars and tensors are both members of a group called tensors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of scalars, vectors, and tensors in mathematics and physics?

options.label: A
options.text: They are complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: They are simple and easy to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: They are used to describe complex interactions and ideas in a relatively simple way.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not used in mathematics and physics.

multiple-choice.question: What type of quantities are scalars, vectors and tensors?
What is the group that scalars and tensors are members of?
What is an example of a tensor used in scientific simulations, car designs, and brain imaging?
What is the property that stress has as a second-order tensor?

options.label: A
options.text: It remains invariant to the coordinate system.

title: How the Band-Aid was invented | Moments of Vision 3 - Jessica Oreck

multiple-choice.question: In what decade did Earle Dickson invent the Band-Aid?
What was the primary reason Earle Dickson created the small bandages?

options.label: B
options.text: To be used in surgical procedures

options.label: C
options.text: To treat minor cuts and burns

options.label: D
options.text: To be used in hospitals for general care

multiple-choice.question: What innovative feature did Earle's Band-Aid design include?

options.label: C
options.text: A bandage with a built-in antibiotic

options.label: D
options.text: A small, self-adhesive bandage lined with crinoline fabric

multiple-choice.question: How did Earle respond to his wife's frequent accidents?

options.label: A
options.text: He was frustrated with her constant injuries

options.label: C
options.text: He was very supportive of her and helped her with her accidents

multiple-choice.question: How many Band-Aids has Johnson and Johnson estimated to have produced?
What was a key marketing strategy employed by Johnson and Johnson to promote Band-Aids?

options.label: B
options.text: They distributed free samples to local stores

options.label: C
options.text: They gave away unlimited Band-Aids to Boy Scout Troops across America

options.label: D
options.text: They partnered with a popular sports team

multiple-choice.question: What problem did Earle face when producing the small bandages?

options.label: A
options.text: They were too expensive to produce

options.label: B
options.text: They were too difficult to apply

options.label: D
options.text: They were too large for his wife's injuries

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Band-Aids in terms of their popularity?

options.label: B
options.text: They were only popular among certain demographics

options.label: D
options.text: They were widely adopted by the general public

multiple-choice.question: How did Earle prevent the adhesive from sticking together?

options.label: C
options.text: He used a different type of adhesive

options.label: D
options.text: He lined them with crinoline fabric

multiple-choice.question: What significance did Band-Aids hold in terms of solving a common problem?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a product that solved a common problem with a simple solution

options.label: B
options.text: It was a major breakthrough in medical technology

options.label: C
options.text: It was a significant marketing achievement

options.label: D
options.text: It was a product that only appealed to a niche market

title: Why some of us don't have one true calling - Emilie Wapnick

multiple-choice.question: What question often causes anxiety for many people?

options.label: B
options.text: What do you want to be when you grow up?

options.label: D
options.text: What is not a suitable option, as it's not a question. However, "What do you want to be when you grow up?" is a more specific option that fits the context.

multiple-choice.question: At what age are we first asked the question "What do you want to be when you grow up?"
What term is used to describe someone with many interests and creative pursuits?
What is one of the strengths of being a multipotentialite?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to focus on one thing

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to combine two or more fields and create something new

multiple-choice.question: What is another strength of being a multipotentialite?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to be a beginner forever

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to rapidly learn and apply new skills

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to focus on one thing for a long time

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to adapt to new situations slowly

multiple-choice.question: What is a term used to describe the ability of multipotentialites to access a lot of intersections and create new ideas?
What is an example of a multipotentialite who has combined two or more fields to create something new?

options.label: A
options.text: Nora Dunn, who is a full-time traveler and freelance writer

options.label: B
options.text: Abe Cajudo, who is a video director, web designer, and Kickstarter consultant

options.label: C
options.text: Sha Hwang and Rachel Binx, who created custom geographically-inspired jewelry

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the superpowers of multipotentialites that is being lost if pressured to narrow their focus?
Why do multipotentialites have a lot of complex, multidimensional problems in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not able to focus on one thing

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not able to learn new skills

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not able to adapt to new situations

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are able to access a lot of intersections and create new ideas

multiple-choice.question: What is the one thing that the speaker hopes people take away from the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more like specialist peers

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on one thing for a long time

options.label: D
options.text: To embrace their inner wiring and follow their curiosity

multiple-choice.question: What question is often asked of people at a young age, but can cause anxiety as they get older?

options.label: B
options.text: What do you want to be when you grow up?

multiple-choice.question: What is the cultural impact of asking the question "What do you want to be when you grow up?"

options.label: A
options.text: It inspires kids to dream about all that they could be

options.label: B
options.text: It encourages kids to focus on one thing

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to anxiety and pressure to choose a single path

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on kids
